policies.title: Economic Freedom & Anti-Cronyism
policies.description: Breaking up the cozy relationship between government and big business benefits all Americans. Government should not pick winners and losers. These policies find support across the political spectrum and represent realistic starting points.

subPolicies.title: Medicare Competitive Bidding
problem: Medicare pays fixed prices set by formula, not market competition
Durable medical equipment costs 2-3x retail prices
No incentive for suppliers to compete on price
Taxpayers and beneficiaries pay inflated costs
Prior competitive bidding pilot saved 42% — then was ended due to industry lobbying
positions: Expand competitive bidding to all durable medical equipment
Apply competitive bidding principles to other Medicare purchases where feasible
Require transparent pricing data
Allow beneficiaries to shop and keep a portion of savings (reference pricing)

framing.forConservatives: Market competition, not government price-fixing. Let suppliers compete.
framing.forProgressives: Stop overpaying corporations. Save Medicare money for actual care.
framing.forEveryone: Why pay $500 for something that costs $100 at the store?

subPolicies.allies: Taxpayer advocates, fiscal conservatives, some healthcare reformers
subPolicies.opposition: Medical equipment suppliers, healthcare industry lobbyists

subPolicies.title: Occupational Licensing Reform
problem: 1 in 4 American workers now needs government permission to work (up from 1 in 20 in the 1950s)
Average license requires $267 in fees, 9 months of training, and an exam
Licenses don't transfer between states — blocks military spouses, movers
Primarily protects existing practitioners from competition, not consumers from harm
Barriers hit hardest for low-income workers, immigrants, and those with criminal records
positions: Universal recognition: Accept valid out-of-state licenses
Sunset reviews: Require periodic justification for all licensing requirements
Least restrictive means: Use certification, bonding, or inspection instead of licensing where possible
Right to earn a living: Require government to prove licensing is necessary, not the worker to prove they're qualified
Clean slate provisions: Remove licensing barriers for rehabilitated offenders in non-sensitive fields

framing.forConservatives: Free market. Right to earn a living. Get government out of the way.
framing.forProgressives: Licensing barriers hurt minorities, immigrants, and the poor. This is economic justice.
framing.forEveryone: You shouldn't need government permission to braid hair or arrange flowers.

subPolicies.allies: Institute for Justice, state policy think tanks, small business groups, workforce development organizations
subPolicies.opposition: Licensed professionals protecting their markets, some trade associations

subPolicies.title: Right to Repair
problem: Manufacturers use software locks, proprietary parts, and withheld documentation to block independent repair
John Deere tractors require dealer visits for basic repairs — farmers can't fix their own equipment
Apple and others void warranties for independent repairs and refuse parts to non-authorized shops
Medical devices locked so hospitals can't perform basic maintenance
Electronics designed with planned obsolescence — can't be economically repaired
positions: Require manufacturers to provide diagnostic tools, repair documentation, and replacement parts
Prohibit software locks that prevent repair
Prohibit voiding warranties solely because of independent repair
Apply to all product categories: agricultural equipment, electronics, appliances, medical devices, vehicles

framing.forConservatives: Property rights. If you bought it, you own it. You should be able to fix what you own.
framing.forProgressives: Environmental sustainability. Consumer protection against corporate control.
framing.forFarmers: Fix your own tractor. Don't wait three weeks for a dealer in planting season.

subPolicies.allies: Farmers' organizations, independent repair shops, consumer advocates, environmental groups, tech repair community
subPolicies.opposition: Major manufacturers (John Deere, Apple, medical device companies), authorized dealer networks

subPolicies.title: Civil Asset Forfeiture Reform
problem: Police can seize property (cash, cars, homes) without ever charging the owner with a crime
Property is 'guilty until proven innocent' — owner must prove it wasn't connected to crime
Law enforcement agencies often keep seized assets, creating profit incentive
Median cash seizure is ~$1,300 — not worth the legal fees to contest
Disproportionately affects low-income and minority communities
positions: Require criminal conviction before permanent forfeiture
Shift burden of proof to government
Redirect forfeiture proceeds to general fund (remove profit incentive)
Require clear and convincing evidence standard at minimum
Provide legal representation for those contesting seizures
Mandatory reporting of all seizures

framing.forConservatives: Property rights. Due process. Limited government. This is legalized theft.
framing.forProgressives: Racial justice. Economic justice. Police accountability.
framing.forEveryone: Your property shouldn't be guilty until you prove it innocent.

subPolicies.allies: Institute for Justice, ACLU, libertarian organizations, criminal justice reform groups
subPolicies.opposition: Law enforcement unions, prosecutors' associations, agencies that benefit from forfeiture funds

subPolicies.title: ESG & Stakeholder Capitalism Opposition
subPolicies.level: State (pension funds, state contracts), Federal (SEC rules)
problem: ESG (Environmental, Social, Governance) scores pressure companies to adopt specific political positions
Major asset managers (BlackRock, Vanguard, State Street) vote YOUR shares for ESG goals without your consent
Banks and insurers deny services based on ESG scores (energy companies, gun manufacturers, etc.)
Fiduciary duty to investors replaced with vague 'stakeholder' obligations
State pension funds forced into ESG investments that may underperform
positions: Fiduciary duty means financial returns: State pension funds must prioritize returns, not ESG goals
Pass-through voting: Asset managers must vote shares as beneficial owners direct, not as managers prefer
No ESG discrimination: Banks and insurers cannot deny services to legal industries based on ESG scores
Disclosure requirements: Companies must disclose ESG-related costs and impacts on returns
Anti-boycott provisions: State contracts cannot exclude companies for political stances

framing.forConservatives: Fiduciary duty. Shareholder rights. Stop politicizing retirement savings.
framing.forProgressives: Ask why billionaire asset managers get to vote your shares for their priorities, not yours.
framing.forEveryone: Your retirement savings should be managed for returns, not political agendas.

subPolicies.allies: State financial officers, energy sector, Second Amendment groups, free market think tanks
subPolicies.opposition: Major asset managers, ESG rating agencies, progressive advocacy groups

subPolicies.title: Healthcare Price Transparency
problem: Patients cannot get prices before receiving care
Same procedure varies 10x between facilities in same city
Insurance 'negotiated rates' are secret — you can't shop
Surprise bills from out-of-network providers
Hospital chargemasters are fiction — no one pays those rates
Existing federal transparency rules (2021) widely ignored, poorly enforced
positions: Enforce existing hospital price transparency rules with real penalties
Require binding upfront estimates for non-emergency care
All-payer claims databases at state level (every insurance payment public)
Real-time eligibility and price lookup tools
Ban gag clauses that prevent price disclosure
Reference pricing: Medicare pays market rate, not inflated hospital rate

framing.forConservatives: Free markets require price information. You can't have competition without prices.
framing.forProgressives: Patients deserve to know what they'll pay. End surprise bills.
framing.forEveryone: You wouldn't buy a car without knowing the price. Why accept that for surgery?

subPolicies.allies: Patient advocates, employers, some insurers, fiscal conservatives
subPolicies.opposition: Hospital systems, some provider groups that benefit from price opacity

subPolicies.title: Environmental Policy: Outcome-Based, State-Driven
problem: Environmental regulations increasingly driven by political agenda rather than measurable outcomes
One-size-fits-all federal mandates ignore regional differences
Permitting delays block infrastructure for years (average NEPA review: 4.5 years)
Regulations used as weapon against disfavored industries regardless of actual environmental impact
Compliance costs fall hardest on small businesses and rural communities
positions: Outcome-based standards: Set measurable environmental goals (air quality, water quality, species population), let states determine how to achieve them
Streamline permitting: Categorical exclusions for proven low-impact activities; concurrent (not sequential) reviews
Cost-benefit requirements: Rigorous analysis of costs vs. environmental benefits for all major rules
State primacy: States with proven track records should have primary implementation authority
Sunset provisions: Regulations expire unless renewed with demonstrated effectiveness

framing.forConservatives: Federalism. States know their environments better than Washington. Focus on results, not process.
framing.forProgressives: Outcome-based standards can achieve better environmental results faster than bureaucratic process.
framing.forEveryone: Clean air and water matter. Decade-long permitting delays don't help the environment.

subPolicies.allies: State environmental agencies, business groups, some conservation organizations focused on outcomes
subPolicies.opposition: National environmental groups invested in federal control, regulatory agencies protecting jurisdiction

policies.title: Food & Health Sovereignty
policies.description: Restore individuals' rights to make their own food and health choices without excessive government interference.

subPolicies.title: Raw Dairy Freedom
problem: Many states ban sale of raw milk despite consumer demand
Federal regulations restrict interstate commerce in raw dairy
Families forced to buy 'shares' in cows to access raw milk legally
Paternalistic regulations ignore informed consumer choice
positions: Legalize raw milk sales with clear labeling requirements
Allow farmers to sell directly to informed consumers
Remove federal barriers to interstate raw dairy commerce
Require warnings but respect consumer autonomy
Protect small dairies from one-size-fits-all regulations
subPolicies.framing: Adults should be free to buy raw milk if they understand the risks. This is about freedom and informed choice.

subPolicies.title: Cottage Food Freedom
problem: Home bakers and cooks face criminal charges for selling food
Unnecessary commercial kitchen requirements block small businesses
Regulations designed for factories applied to home operations
Prevents entrepreneurship and local food systems
positions: Legalize home food businesses with gross sales cap (e.g., $50k/year)
Allow direct sales at farmers markets and online
Require labeling, not commercial kitchens
Protect traditional home food businesses
Focus on disclosure, not prohibition
subPolicies.framing: A grandmother shouldn't need a $50,000 commercial kitchen to sell cookies. Let people cook.

subPolicies.title: Medical Freedom & Informed Consent
problem: Medical mandates override individual autonomy
Vaccine requirements for employment and education expanding
Limited informed consent in emergency situations
Alternative treatments suppressed or banned
One-size-fits-all mandates ignore individual health conditions
positions: Protect medical choice and informed consent
Ban vaccine passports and employment mandates
Preserve religious and conscience exemptions
Ensure access to alternative treatments (right to try)
No emergency orders that bypass informed consent
subPolicies.framing: Your body, your choice. Medical freedom is fundamental—not negotiable.

policies.title: Property Rights
policies.description: Strengthen individual property rights against government overreach and private restrictions.

subPolicies.title: HOA Reform
problem: HOAs wield unchecked power over homeowners
Fines and liens for minor violations (wrong paint color, grass height)
Lack of due process and accountability
Difficult to change rules or remove bad boards
Creates hostile living environments
positions: Limit HOA fine and lien authority
Require majority approval for new restrictions
Provide homeowner bill of rights with due process protections
Prohibit foreclosure for unpaid fines under $5,000
Allow opt-out for certain restrictions (solar, gardens, political signs)
subPolicies.framing: You should own your home—not the other way around. HOAs need limits.

subPolicies.title: Eminent Domain Reform
problem: Government can seize private property for private development
Low-ball compensation
Abuse in urban renewal projects
'Public use' interpreted far too broadly
Little recourse for property owners
positions: Restrict eminent domain to genuine public use (roads, utilities)
Ban takings for private development or tax revenue
Require fair market value plus 50% premium for forced sales
Strong protections for homes, farms, and small businesses
Burden of proof on government
subPolicies.framing: Your home isn't a revenue opportunity for developers. Eminent domain should be rare and compensated fairly.

subPolicies.title: Mineral and Subsurface Rights
problem: Property owners don't control mineral rights under their land
Energy companies can drill without surface owner consent
Split estates create conflicts and unfair outcomes
Landowners bear costs but don't share profits
positions: Require surface owner consent for mineral extraction
Reunify split estates where feasible
Fair compensation for surface damage
Protect groundwater and surface property
Respect both surface and mineral rights holders
subPolicies.framing: If it's your land, you should have a say in what happens on it and under it.

policies.title: Government Accountability & Reform
policies.description: Implement strict accountability measures to end corruption and restore public trust in government.

subPolicies.title: Congressional Stock Trading Ban
problem: Members of Congress trade stocks based on confidential information
Outperform market by suspicious margins
Massive conflicts of interest in policy-making
Erodes public trust
Current 'disclosure' rules are ineffective
positions: Complete ban on stock trading for Members of Congress and immediate family
Require divestment or blind trusts upon taking office
Extend ban to senior executive branch officials
Criminal penalties for violations
Apply retroactively to recent suspicious trades
subPolicies.framing: If you serve in Congress, you shouldn't get rich trading on inside information. Ban it completely.

subPolicies.title: Term Limits
problem: Career politicians lose touch with constituents
Seniority system entrenches power
Incumbency advantage makes competition impossible
Lobbyists prey on long-term relationships
Congress becomes out-of-touch ruling class
positions: 12-year limit for House and Senate combined
No exemptions or exceptions
Requires constitutional amendment (Article V convention likely needed)
Primary focus: state-level advocacy for convention
subPolicies.framing: Public service shouldn't be a lifetime career. Term limits would break the stranglehold of career politicians.

subPolicies.title: End Lobbying / Citizen Portal
problem: Lobbyists write legislation and control access to lawmakers
Ordinary citizens have no comparable influence
Corporate money dominates policy-making
Revolving door between government and lobbying firms
positions: Create public 'Citizen Portal' for constituents to present bills
Require all bill drafts to be public before introduction
Ban former Members of Congress from lobbying for 10 years
Heavy penalties for undisclosed lobbying
Empower citizens to bypass lobbying gatekeepers
subPolicies.framing: Why do corporations get to write laws, but citizens don't? Open the process to everyone.

subPolicies.title: Regulatory Reform & Accountability
problem: Unelected bureaucrats make rules with force of law
No congressional approval required
Agencies reinterpret statutes to expand their power
Regulations accumulate endlessly—never removed
Costs hidden and never analyzed
positions: Require congressional approval for all major regulations
Sunset clauses—regulations expire unless renewed
Cost-benefit analysis for every rule
Agencies cannot expand authority beyond clear statutory language
Citizens can challenge regulations in expedited judicial review
subPolicies.framing: Agencies should execute the law—not write it. Congress must reclaim its authority.

subPolicies.title: Legislative Transparency & Reform
problem: Bills dropped at midnight with no time to read
Massive omnibus bills hide controversial provisions
Last-minute amendments sneak through
No one knows what they're voting on
positions: Mandatory 72-hour public review period for all bills
Single-subject rule for legislation
No omnibus bills over 100 pages
All amendments public 24 hours before vote
Plain-language summaries required
subPolicies.framing: Representatives should read what they vote on. So should citizens.

subPolicies.title: Emergency Powers Reform
problem: Executive emergency powers used indefinitely
No meaningful congressional oversight or renewal
33+ 'emergencies' currently in effect
COVID showed executive overreach dangers
State governors wield unchecked emergency authority
positions: Emergency orders expire after 30 days unless renewed by legislature
No emergency can suspend constitutional rights
Strict separation of powers—no executive lawmaking
Judicial review available immediately
Clear limits on what constitutes an emergency
subPolicies.framing: Emergencies shouldn't mean dictatorship. Restore checks and balances.

policies.title: Election Integrity
policies.description: Ensure secure, transparent, and trustworthy elections through common-sense safeguards.

subPolicies.title: Voter ID Requirements
problem: Many states allow voting without verifying identity
Opens door to fraud and undermines confidence
Inconsistent standards create confusion
positions: Require government-issued photo ID to vote
Provide free voter ID to anyone who needs one
Accept multiple forms (driver's license, passport, military ID, state ID)
Reasonable accommodations for elderly and disabled
subPolicies.framing: You need an ID to buy beer—why not to vote? Free ID plus voter ID requirement is common sense.

subPolicies.title: Paper Ballot Requirement
problem: Electronic-only voting machines have no audit trail
Vulnerable to hacking and malfunction
Difficult to verify accuracy
No way to recount if needed
positions: Require paper ballots for all elections
Electronic machines can assist but must produce paper record
Voter verifies paper ballot before casting
Paper is the official record for recounts
subPolicies.framing: Paper ballots are simple, transparent, and trustworthy. High-tech isn't always better.

subPolicies.title: Chain of Custody & Security
problem: Ballots transported without clear tracking
Unsecured drop boxes
Gaps in custody records
Difficult to trace irregularities
positions: Strict chain-of-custody protocols for all ballots
Secured, monitored drop boxes (if used)
Real-time tracking and documentation
Bipartisan observation at every step
Criminal penalties for chain-of-custody violations
subPolicies.framing: We track Amazon packages—why not ballots? Tight security builds trust.

subPolicies.title: Timely Results & Audits
problem: Days or weeks to count votes
Results announced before counting complete
Rare and inconsistent audits
Erodes public confidence
positions: Results announced same night or within 24 hours
Mandatory random audits of 5-10% of precincts
Full forensic audit available upon petition or close results
Public observation of counting process
subPolicies.framing: France counts 40 million votes in 24 hours. America can do better.

subPolicies.title: Voter Roll Maintenance
problem: Rolls include deceased voters, moved voters, duplicates
States don't share data
Outdated rolls enable fraud and mistakes
positions: Annual voter roll updates
Cross-state database to prevent double registration
Remove deceased and relocated voters promptly
Verify citizenship
Easy re-registration if removed in error
subPolicies.framing: Clean voter rolls protect everyone's vote. Regular maintenance is basic election hygiene.

policies.title: Constitutional Rights
policies.description: Defend fundamental constitutional liberties against government and corporate overreach.

subPolicies.title: Free Speech & Anti-Censorship
problem: Tech platforms censor speech under government pressure
Viewpoint-based content moderation
Deplatforming and shadow-banning
Collusion between government and big tech
Loss of digital public square
positions: Ban government from pressuring platforms to censor lawful speech
Classify major platforms as common carriers (neutrality requirements)
Transparency in content moderation decisions
Right to appeal and judicial review for deplatforming
Protect anonymous speech
subPolicies.framing: Free speech doesn't end online. Big Tech shouldn't be the speech police.

subPolicies.title: Individual Liberty & Conscience Protections
problem: Religious and conscience objections overridden by mandates
Private beliefs punished through civil penalties
Compelled speech (pronouns, statements)
Loss of professional licenses for beliefs
positions: Strong religious freedom protections (RFRA-style)
No compelled speech
Conscience protections for medical professionals
Protect employment and education from viewpoint discrimination
Right to opt out of ideologically-driven training or statements
subPolicies.framing: You shouldn't lose your job for your beliefs. Conscience and liberty go hand-in-hand.

subPolicies.title: Reproductive Rights & Bodily Autonomy
problem: Post-Roe patchwork of state laws
Access to abortion and contraception varies widely
Government interference in personal medical decisions
positions: Support state-level decision-making post-Dobbs
Protect access to contraception
Oppose late-term abortion restrictions with exceptions for health/life
Ensure informed consent and safety standards
Respect diverse views within membership
subPolicies.framing: Personal medical decisions should remain personal. Common-sense laws respect both life and liberty.

subPolicies.title: Second Amendment Rights
problem: Incremental restrictions on gun ownership
Red flag laws without due process
Arbitrary 'assault weapon' bans
Restrictions on law-abiding citizens, not criminals
positions: Defend individual right to bear arms
Oppose arbitrary bans and magazine limits
Due process required for any restriction (red flag reforms)
National concealed-carry reciprocity
Focus enforcement on criminals, not lawful owners
subPolicies.framing: The Second Amendment isn't negotiable. Enforce existing laws—don't punish law-abiding citizens.

subPolicies.title: Parental Rights in Education
problem: Schools withhold information from parents
Parents excluded from curriculum decisions
Gender and sexuality instruction without parental consent
Schools override parental authority
positions: Parents have final authority over their children's education and medical care
Transparent curriculum with opt-out rights
No gender transition without parental knowledge and consent
Right to know what schools teach
Protect teachers who respect parental rights
subPolicies.framing: Parents—not bureaucrats—raise children. Schools should educate, not indoctrinate.

subPolicies.title: Homeschool Freedom & Educational Choice
problem: Excessive homeschool regulations in some states
Barriers to educational choice
Homeschoolers excluded from extracurriculars
Lack of education savings accounts
positions: Protect homeschooling with minimal regulation
Education savings accounts (ESAs) for all families
Open extracurriculars and sports to homeschoolers
Tax credits for educational expenses
Support charter, private, and alternative education options
subPolicies.framing: Parents know what's best for their kids. School choice empowers families.

policies.title: Technology & Communications Freedom
policies.description: Protect digital rights, privacy, and free expression in the modern technology landscape.

subPolicies.title: Digital Privacy & Data Protection
problem: Companies collect and sell personal data without meaningful consent
Government surveillance programs lack oversight
Data breaches expose millions
No right to deletion or portability
positions: Require explicit opt-in consent for data collection
Right to access, delete, and port personal data
Heavy penalties for data breaches and misuse
Limit government data collection without warrant
Transparency in algorithmic decision-making
subPolicies.framing: Your data is yours. Companies should ask permission—not forgiveness.

subPolicies.title: Net Neutrality & Common Carrier Rules
problem: ISPs can throttle or block content
Paid prioritization creates two-tier internet
Limited competition gives ISPs monopoly power
positions: Treat ISPs as common carriers—no blocking, throttling, or paid prioritization
Encourage infrastructure competition
Local governments shouldn't grant monopolies
Transparent network management practices
subPolicies.framing: The internet should be open and equal. No corporate gatekeepers.

policies.title: Monetary & Financial Reform
policies.description: Reform the financial system to end manipulation, restore sound money, and protect savers.

subPolicies.title: Federal Reserve Audit & Reform
problem: Federal Reserve operates with minimal oversight
Inflation taxes savers and wage-earners
Monetary policy favors asset-holders
Lack of transparency and accountability
positions: Full audit of Federal Reserve operations
Congressional oversight of monetary policy
End or limit quantitative easing
Stabilize currency value
Explore alternatives to fiat monetary system
subPolicies.framing: Why is the Fed the only agency Congress won't audit? Transparency is accountability.

subPolicies.title: Sound Money & Inflation Control
problem: Persistent inflation erodes purchasing power
Savings lose value over time
Debt-based economy punishes savers
No constraint on money creation
positions: Return to sound money principles
Limit money supply growth
Explore gold standard or commodity backing
Protect value of savings and wages
End bailouts and moral hazard
subPolicies.framing: Your paycheck should hold its value. Inflation is a hidden tax on working people.

policies.title: Political System Reform
policies.description: Break the two-party duopoly and restore competitive, representative democracy.

subPolicies.title: Ballot Access & Third-Party Representation
problem: Two-party system entrenched by ballot access laws
Difficult for independents and third parties to compete
Arbitrary signature requirements and deadlines
Voters lack real choice
positions: Lower ballot access thresholds
Standardize signature requirements
Allow fusion voting (multiple parties nominating same candidate)
Public funding or vouchers for all qualified candidates
End two-party debate monopoly
subPolicies.framing: Two parties don't represent everyone. Open the system to competition.

subPolicies.title: Campaign Finance Reform
problem: Unlimited money in politics
Super PACs and dark money dominate
Small donors irrelevant
Candidates beholden to wealthy donors
positions: Public financing option for candidates
Matching funds for small donations
Full transparency—no dark money
Limits on corporate and union political spending
Strengthen anti-coordination rules
subPolicies.framing: Big money shouldn't buy elections. Amplify small donors, expose dark money.

policies.title: Foreign Policy & National Interest
policies.description: Put American interests first, end forever wars, and restore constitutional war powers.

subPolicies.title: End Forever Wars & Restrain Military Interventionism
problem: Endless military commitments with no clear goals
Trillions spent on nation-building abroad
Thousands of American lives lost
Congress abdicates war-making authority
positions: No military action without congressional declaration of war
Withdraw from indefinite deployments
Focus military on defense, not nation-building
Sunset all authorizations for use of military force (AUMFs)
Prioritize diplomacy and restraint
subPolicies.framing: Our military defends America—not the world. End forever wars and bring troops home.

subPolicies.title: Trade & Economic Sovereignty
problem: Trade agreements favor multinational corporations
Job losses to offshoring
Dependence on adversarial nations for critical goods
Trade deficits drain wealth
positions: Fair trade—not unconditional free trade
Prioritize American manufacturing and workers
End dependence on China for critical supplies
Use tariffs to protect strategic industries
No trade agreements that override U.S. law
subPolicies.framing: Trade should benefit Americans—not just corporations. Economic security is national security.

policies.title: Healthcare System Reform
policies.description: Lower costs, increase choice, and restore market forces to healthcare.

subPolicies.title: Price Transparency & Competition
problem: Patients can't get prices before care
No ability to shop for healthcare
Insurance hides negotiated rates
Costs spiral without market discipline
positions: Require upfront, binding price quotes for all non-emergency care
Publish negotiated rates between insurers and providers
Allow patients to shop and keep savings
Increase competition by removing restrictions
Standardize billing and coding
subPolicies.framing: You can't have a free market without prices. Healthcare transparency is common sense.

subPolicies.title: Insurance & Care Decoupling
problem: Insurance tied to employment
Lose job, lose coverage
No portability or choice
Tax code subsidizes employer plans, penalizes individuals
positions: End tax preference for employer-based insurance
Universal tax deduction for health expenses
Portable, individually-owned plans
Health savings accounts (HSAs) for all
Allow purchase across state lines
subPolicies.framing: Health insurance should follow you—not your job. Decouple coverage from employment.

policies.title: Education Reform
policies.description: Empower parents, expand choice, and refocus education on knowledge and skills.

subPolicies.title: School Choice & Education Savings Accounts
problem: Families trapped in failing schools
Public education monopoly
No alternatives for low-income families
One-size-fits-all approach
positions: Universal education savings accounts (ESAs)
Money follows the student
Support public, charter, private, and homeschool options
Tax credits for educational expenses
Let parents choose what's best
subPolicies.framing: Every family deserves school choice—not just the wealthy. Fund students, not systems.

subPolicies.title: Curriculum Transparency & Parental Rights
problem: Parents don't know what schools teach
Controversial content without notification
Schools override parental authority
No meaningful input or opt-out
positions: All curriculum materials publicly available online
Parental notification and opt-out rights
No gender or sexuality instruction without explicit consent
Ban critical race theory and divisive ideologies
Refocus on knowledge, not activism
subPolicies.framing: Parents have a right to know—and approve—what their kids are taught.

policies.title: Social Security Reform
policies.description: Save Social Security for current retirees while giving younger workers better options.

subPolicies.title: Voluntary Private Accounts for Younger Workers
problem: Social Security returns are negative for younger workers
Trust fund going broke
No ownership or inheritance of contributions
Younger workers pay for current retirees with no guarantee
positions: Allow workers under 40 to opt into private retirement accounts
Keep Social Security for current and near-retirees
Private accounts earn market returns and are inheritable
Guarantee safety net for those who opt in
Transition over decades
subPolicies.framing: Younger workers deserve ownership and better returns. Reform now to save the system.

subPolicies.title: Means Testing & Benefit Adjustments
problem: Wealthy retirees receive full benefits
System unsustainable without changes
Benefits exceed contributions for high earners
positions: Reduce benefits for wealthy retirees (means testing)
Raise retirement age for younger workers
Adjust cost-of-living formulas
Protect benefits for low- and middle-income retirees
Phase in changes gradually
subPolicies.framing: Tough choices now prevent collapse later. Protect those who need it most.

policies.title: Tax Reform
policies.description: Simplify the tax code, lower rates, and eliminate special-interest loopholes.

subPolicies.title: Flat or Consumption Tax
problem: Complex tax code favors those who can afford accountants
Loopholes and carve-outs distort economy
Income tax punishes productivity
IRS enforcement burdens ordinary taxpayers
positions: Replace income tax with flat tax or national sales tax (FairTax)
Abolish IRS or drastically reduce its size
Universal deduction to protect low earners
Eliminate all deductions and credits
Simplicity and transparency
subPolicies.framing: Tax everyone fairly at the same rate. No more loopholes, no more IRS abuses.

subPolicies.title: Eliminate Carve-Outs & Special Interests
problem: Tax code riddled with special-interest breaks
Corporations and wealthy exploit loopholes
Complexity hides handouts
Ordinary taxpayers pay more
positions: Eliminate all corporate tax breaks and subsidies
No targeted tax credits for specific industries
Lower rates, broaden base
Treat all income equally (wages, capital gains, dividends)
Transparency in tax expenditures
subPolicies.framing: Lower rates for everyone—not special deals for insiders. Simplify and level the playing field.

policies.title: Drug Policy Reform
policies.description: End the failed war on drugs with evidence-based policies focused on treatment and liberty.

subPolicies.title: Decriminalize & Focus on Treatment
problem: War on drugs has failed for 50 years
Mass incarceration without reducing use
Ruined lives over nonviolent offenses
Lack of treatment options
positions: Decriminalize personal drug possession
Expand treatment and recovery programs
Expunge nonviolent drug offenses
Focus enforcement on trafficking and violence
Treat addiction as health issue, not crime
subPolicies.framing: Locking people up for addiction doesn't work. Treatment saves lives.

subPolicies.title: Marijuana Legalization
problem: Federal prohibition despite state legalization
Arrests for marijuana use continue
Lost tax revenue and economic opportunity
Inconsistent laws create confusion
positions: Legalize marijuana at federal level
Expunge marijuana convictions
Tax and regulate like alcohol
Allow states to set own policies
End federal interference in state-legal marijuana
subPolicies.framing: Marijuana prohibition has failed. Legalize, regulate, and tax it.

policies.title: Housing Reform
policies.description: Address the housing affordability crisis through deregulation and market-based solutions.

subPolicies.title: Zoning & Land Use Reform
problem: Restrictive zoning limits housing supply
Single-family-only zoning in most areas
NIMBYism blocks new development
Housing costs soar as supply constrained
positions: Legalize multi-family and accessory dwelling units (ADUs)
Reduce minimum lot sizes and setback requirements
Expedite permitting for housing
Override exclusionary zoning
Let supply meet demand
subPolicies.framing: Build more housing, lower the cost. Zoning rules make housing unaffordable.

subPolicies.title: Reduce Construction Costs & Regulations
problem: Excessive building codes raise costs
Environmental reviews delay projects for years
Prevailing wage laws increase expenses
Regulatory compliance adds 20-30% to costs
positions: Streamline building codes—adopt model codes
Expedite environmental reviews for housing
Reform or eliminate prevailing wage mandates
Allow innovative construction methods (modular, 3D printing)
Cut red tape to lower costs
subPolicies.framing: Regulations price people out of homes. Cut the red tape and build.
